MrTAteMyBallsJun 29 at 10:01 PM
Masterpiece

This review is a cumulative review of all 3 titles since they are one story arc.

I have been a star wars kid since I was about 5. That would have been in 1985, when the Atari would have been the king of home video game consoles. How things have changed!!!!

First, the developers nailed the story mode. You want to feel like you are actually a character in a Star Wars movie?? You want to face Vader in a climactic showdown? You want to learn force powers from Vader himself???? This game gives you everything that you want!!!!!! This is the first and only game that I have lost myself in. I just totally gave in and I was there with these characters.

Second, the gameplay mechanics are wonderful. Holding the Quest controller is a bit like the hilt of a sword so it feels very intuitive and the light saber really feels connected to your body.

Third, the Jedi Training room IS the major feature of the game. Wield 2 light sabers, use the force to throw things, robots, or people around. Choke enemies. Throw your light saber around like a boomerang while force throwing storm troopers with your other hand. Just amazing. Feel like a powerful jedi who can wreak havoc on an army singlehandedly. Try out Darth Mauls two sided saber that looks really cool but is apparently not very useful...haha.
Sometime in the middle of the dojo levels....something special and amazing happens. I wont spoil it but i am pretty sure i squeeled when it happened.

4th, actually the game looks great. I am not sure how they are doing this on a mobile processor....But it works.


Developers: PLEASE PLEASE MAKE MORE. There is plenty of material to mine for more star wars stories. The quest was built for star wars. I have this game for 7 months now and still play the Jedi Training room at least twice a week. It's just too much fun. But I need another story to be a part of. Do It!!!!

BruceinAKMar 6 at 11:08 AM
Great game but with limitations

First, let me say that Im relatively new to gaming. Also, much of what I say here applies to all three games.

1) The software that handles the light saber needs work. I dont know if the developers of this series wrote their own or licensed code from someone else, but your motions with the saber, and even using the force with a hand, do not have consistent results. Vader Immortal is only fair compared to Beat Saber or Ninja Assassins in this regard.

2) The plot needs some branch points built in. As it is, there is only one path forward, and things literally come to a halt while it waits for you to do whatever you have to do correctly. I recall reading a comment by someone else who said this limitation was imposed by the Star Wars copyright holders who sold this more advanced capability to other game developers. I dont know. Its just frustrating because it limits what is otherwise a great game.

3) Despite the previously described issues I gave this 5 stars because its still a lot of fun. Im admittedly a Star Wars geek (nearly 70 years old, and need to grow up!) and really enjoy the environment. The basic artwork is great, and the basic plot is fun. Ive long been a sci-fi book reader, but participatory sci-fi is a kick. Being able to actually move is SO much better than the thumb workout you get on an Xbox or Play Station.

Conclusion: I would recommend this to other Star Wars fans. Heavy duty gamers may find it too elementary.

NOTE TO THE DEVELOPERS: I would be willing to pay for an upgrade to all three parts of Vader if you addressed issues 1 and 2.

I'll Reserve My Ire

To start this off, I am not a Star Wars fan, so I'm not blinded by nostalgia and the dazzling ball of profit that is the Star Wars IP. If you are, then just buy this, it's only $10 and you'll have a fun time.

If you're not, though... the story is weak, and lightsaber fighting doesn't feel natural (they've had the ability to dismember enemies based on where you cut them for years now, 2003's Jedi Academy had this as I recall. I'm not asking for spurting blood in a T-rated game, I'm just asking that my saber fights feel somewhat real, and my enemies taking 5 hits and then exploding doesn't qualify as such.) The voice acting for the droid is unconscionably irritating, and it runs pretty darn badly on Quest. Have yet to try the Link version of the game, but given that I have a fairly beefy computer I'll probably be more satisfied with that. ASW does a pretty good job of covering up a mediocre framerate, but... still, it's noticeable.

On a positive note, the game looks pretty good and the force gameplay is very fun. Additionally, the comfort settings they've added are pretty solid, and this game rarely makes me queasy (and when it does, it's due to a poor framerate and not to any of the developers' design choices.)

So, I'll reserve my ire for things that actually suck on Quest, like Guns N Stories. This is a pretty okay game, and picking up an episode wouldn't do you any harm. Just make sure you buy this one (ep. 3) as lightsaber dojo, the most replayable part of the entire game, is fully fleshed out in this episode, with force choking, lightsaber throwing, blaster-shooting and thermal detonators. The first one literally just has lightsabers and training droids, making it a pretty poor way to spend your time in my opinion.

All in all, a very solid vr title and a must by for oculus owners.

As Someone Who Didn't Play Ep 1&2

Alright listen, the price tag is bit steep considering the amount of content you get, so I didn't bother with the first two and skipped to the thrilling conclusion. This review is for those thinking of doing the same.

Let's start with the positives. This game looks fantastic and delivers an exciting Star Wars experience. The characters, set pieces, and action sequences are genuinely interesting and well done. Also, wielding a lightsaber and using the force feels great. I was engaged from beginning to end.

Now, the negatives. It's short. Really short. If you don't plan on bringing your Quest to parties for other people to try this game, it might not be much for your buck. But, if you're a party goer or plan to spend time fighting waves of enemies in the lightsaber dojo (there are unlockables to be gained), this is worth it. One thing this game does that I don't like is lock you in place for cutscenes where it'd be nice for you to walk around. But that's just a nitpick. One more thing: since it's episode 3, there's no tutorial. But if you've usee vr, you'll quickly find the controls are 95% intuitive.

In the end, if you care about lightsaber fighting more than the story, you can skip to this one. If you're looking for a complete experience, get them all.
